The **Vegas Golden Knights** are an [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice
hockey") team based in the [Las Vegas metropolitan
area](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley "Las Vegas Valley"). The team began play in the
[2017–18 NHL season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_NHL_season "2017–18 NHL season"),
and is a member of the [Pacific Division](/wiki/Pacific_Division_\(NHL\)
"Pacific Division \(NHL\)") of the [Western
Conference](/wiki/Western_Conference_\(NHL\) "Western Conference \(NHL\)") of
the [National Hockey League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey
League") (NHL). The team is owned by Black Knight Sports & Entertainment, a
[consortium](/wiki/Consortium "Consortium") led by [Bill
Foley](/wiki/William_P._Foley "William P. Foley") and the [Maloof
family](/wiki/Maloof_family "Maloof family").[4] The team plays its home games
at [T-Mobile Arena](/wiki/T-Mobile_Arena "T-Mobile Arena") on the [Las Vegas
Strip](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip "Las Vegas Strip") in [Paradise,
Nevada](/wiki/Paradise,_Nevada "Paradise, Nevada").[5]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Background and
establishment[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Background and establishment")]

The [NHL has had a presence in Las Vegas since
1991](/wiki/Sports_in_the_Las_Vegas_metropolitan_area#National_Hockey_League
"Sports in the Las Vegas metropolitan area"), when [an outdoor
game](/wiki/1991_outdoor_NHL_game_in_Las_Vegas "1991 outdoor NHL game in Las
Vegas") was held in Las Vegas, with the [Los Angeles
Kings](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings "Los Angeles Kings") facing the [New York
Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New York Rangers") outside [Caesars
Palace](/wiki/Caesars_Palace "Caesars Palace") in a preseason exhibition game.
The city has since hosted the [Frozen Fury](/wiki/Frozen_Fury "Frozen Fury"),
a preseason competition between the Los Angeles Kings and the [Colorado
Avalanche](/wiki/Colorado_Avalanche "Colorado Avalanche"), and the [NHL
Awards](/wiki/NHL_Awards "NHL Awards") ceremonies have been held in Las Vegas
since 2009.[6] In 2009, the media speculated about a plan involving Hollywood
producer [Jerry Bruckheimer](/wiki/Jerry_Bruckheimer "Jerry Bruckheimer") to
move the [Phoenix Coyotes](/wiki/Phoenix_Coyotes "Phoenix Coyotes") to
Nevada.[7]

Rumors of a Las Vegas expansion team surfaced again in August 2014, pointing
to a [new indoor arena](/wiki/T-Mobile_Arena "T-Mobile Arena") on the Strip
(built as a joint venture between [Anschutz Entertainment
Group](/wiki/Anschutz_Entertainment_Group "Anschutz Entertainment Group"),
owners of the [Los Angeles Kings](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings "Los Angeles
Kings"), and [MGM Resorts International](/wiki/MGM_Resorts_International "MGM
Resorts International")) as the potential home arena, although these rumors
were denied by the league.[8][9][10] In November 2014, an unconfirmed report
stated that the league had selected billionaire businessman [Bill
Foley](/wiki/William_P._Foley "William P. Foley") and the [Maloof
family](/wiki/Maloof_family "Maloof family") (former owners of the [National
Basketball Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National
Basketball Association")'s [Sacramento Kings](/wiki/Sacramento_Kings
"Sacramento Kings"), and founders of the [Palms Casino
Resort](/wiki/Palms_Casino_Resort "Palms Casino Resort")) to lead the
ownership group for a Las Vegas expansion team.[11][12] In December 2014, the
NHL's board of governors decided to allow Foley to hold a season ticket drive
to gauge interest in a Las Vegas team, though league commissioner [Gary
Bettman](/wiki/Gary_Bettman "Gary Bettman") also warned the media to "[not]
make more out of this than it is".[13][14] The season ticket drive began in
February 2015, with interested parties placing ten percent deposits for the
2016–17 season.[15] The drive drew 5,000 deposits in its first day and a half,
and reached its goal of 10,000 deposits by April 2015.[15][16]

In June 2015, the league officially opened the window for prospective owners
to bid on expansion teams. By this point, Foley had secured more than 13,200
season-ticket deposits. Two expansion applications were submitted: Foley's
application for a Las Vegas team, and a bid from [Quebecor](/wiki/Quebecor
"Quebecor") to revive the [Quebec Nordiques](/wiki/Quebec_Nordiques "Quebec
Nordiques") at a [new arena](/wiki/Centre_Vid%C3%A9otron "Centre Vidéotron")
in [Quebec City](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec City"). Both Las Vegas and Quebec
were invited to move into Phase II of the league expansion bid in August
2015,[17] and subsequently advanced to Phase III.

At the league owners' meeting on June 22, 2016, in Las Vegas, the Las Vegas
expansion bid was approved by a unanimous vote, with play to begin in the
[2017–18 NHL season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_NHL_season "2017–18 NHL
season").[18] The team became the first [major professional sports
franchise](/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada
"Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada") to be
[based in Las Vegas](/wiki/Sports_in_the_Las_Vegas_metropolitan_area "Sports
in the Las Vegas metropolitan area"), and the first NHL expansion team since
2000.[19] Foley committed to pay the league's $500 million expansion fee[20]
and began the process of hiring the team's principal staff and determining its
official identity. Foley announced that former [Washington
Capitals](/wiki/Washington_Capitals "Washington Capitals") general manager
[George McPhee](/wiki/George_McPhee "George McPhee") would be the franchise's
first general manager.[21] On November 22, 2016, the name was revealed as the
Vegas Golden Knights.

### Start of operations:
2017–present[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Start of operations: 2017–present")]

On March 1, 2017 (coinciding with the league's trade deadline), the team
completed its expansion fee payments and filings, making it eligible to
formally begin operations such as free agent acquisition, and participation in
league meetings.[22] Five days later, the Golden Knights made their first
personnel move by signing [Reid Duke](/wiki/Reid_Duke_\(ice_hockey\) "Reid
Duke \(ice hockey\)") to a three-year entry-level contract.[23][24]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Gerard_Gallant_2018-02-04_2.jpg/220px-
Gerard_Gallant_2018-02-04_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gerard_Gallant_2018-02-04_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gerard_Gallant_2018-02-04_2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Gerard Gallant](/wiki/Gerard_Gallant "Gerard Gallant") coaching the Golden
Knights during their inaugural [2017–18](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_NHL_season
"2017–18 NHL season") season. Gallant was named as the head coach in April
2017.

The team announced inaugural head coach [Gerard Gallant](/wiki/Gerard_Gallant
"Gerard Gallant") on April 13, 2017.[25] Over the next two months, the Golden
Knights developed their [farm system](/wiki/Farm_team#Ice_hockey "Farm team"),
announcing affiliations with the [Chicago Wolves](/wiki/Chicago_Wolves
"Chicago Wolves") of the [American Hockey League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League
"American Hockey League") and the [Quad City
Mallards](/wiki/Quad_City_Mallards "Quad City Mallards") of the
[ECHL](/wiki/ECHL "ECHL").[26][27]

The team participated in the [2017 NHL Expansion
Draft](/wiki/2017_NHL_Expansion_Draft "2017 NHL Expansion Draft") on June 21,
2017, selecting an available player from all 30 teams in the NHL. The draft
picks were announced at T-Mobile Arena during the [NHL
Awards](/wiki/NHL_Awards "NHL Awards") ceremony. Some notable selections
included goalie [Marc-Andre Fleury](/wiki/Marc-Andr%C3%A9_Fleury "Marc-André
Fleury") from the [Pittsburgh Penguins](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh
Penguins") and winger [James Neal](/wiki/James_Neal_\(ice_hockey\) "James Neal
\(ice hockey\)") from the [Nashville Predators](/wiki/Nashville_Predators
"Nashville Predators"). At the [2017 NHL Entry
Draft](/wiki/2017_NHL_Entry_Draft "2017 NHL Entry Draft"), [Cody
Glass](/wiki/Cody_Glass "Cody Glass") was the first player selected by the
Golden Knights. The Golden Knights played their first game on October 6
against the [Dallas Stars](/wiki/Dallas_Stars "Dallas Stars") with Neal
scoring the franchise's first two goals en route to their first victory.[28]

The team's inaugural home game was played on October 10, 2017, hosting the
[Arizona Coyotes](/wiki/Arizona_Coyotes "Arizona Coyotes") as the second game
of a home-and-home series. In the aftermath of the [October 1 mass
shooting](/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_shooting "2017 Las Vegas shooting"), the pre-
game ceremonies honored the victims of the attack, and the team issued an
appeal for donations to its charitable arm.[29] With their 5–2 win, the Golden
Knights increased their unbeaten streak to start the season to 3–0, an NHL
record for an expansion team.[30][31][32] The Golden Knights are the first
team in NHL history to have started their inaugural season winning eight of
their first nine games. During their tenth game, goaltender [Oscar
Dansk](/wiki/Oscar_Dansk "Oscar Dansk") was injured becoming the third Golden
Knights' goaltender to be injured during the season after losing starters
Fleury and the recently acquired [Malcolm Subban](/wiki/Malcolm_Subban
"Malcolm Subban"), forcing the team to start a fourth goaltender in 11 games
with [Maxime Lagace](/wiki/Maxime_Lagac%C3%A9 "Maxime Lagacé").[33] Fifteen
games into the season, [Vadim Shipachyov](/wiki/Vadim_Shipachyov "Vadim
Shipachyov") became the first player to retire from the NHL as a Golden Knight
when he decided to return to the [Kontinental Hockey
League](/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League "Kontinental Hockey League"). In
December, the Golden Knights set another NHL expansion team record of six
straight wins, a record they had previously missed when they lost their tenth
game of the season, and established a new NHL record with eight straight
wins.[34][35][36] On February 1, 2018, the Golden Knights set the expansion
team record for wins in a debut season with 34 wins after only 50 games,[37]
and then on February 21, 2018, set a record for most points by an expansion
team in the inaugural season with 84.[38] On March 26, the Golden Knights
became the first team since the [Edmonton Oilers](/wiki/Edmonton_Oilers
"Edmonton Oilers") and [Hartford Whalers](/wiki/Hartford_Whalers "Hartford
Whalers") in the [1979–80 season](/wiki/1979%E2%80%9380_NHL_season "1979–80
NHL season") to make the playoffs in their inaugural season in the league.[39]
On March 31, the Knights clinched the Pacific Division title, becoming the
first true expansion team in the [four major
sports](/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada
"Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada") to win
its division in its inaugural season (not counting all-expansion divisions, as
was the case in the [1967–68 season](/wiki/1967%E2%80%9368_NHL_season "1967–68
NHL season")).[40] They had led the Pacific since December 23.

On April 11, the franchise won its first playoff game in a [1–0
victory](/wiki/2018_Stanley_Cup_playoffs#\(P1\)_Vegas_Golden_Knights_vs._\(WC1\)_Los_Angeles_Kings
"2018 Stanley Cup playoffs") over the [Los Angeles
Kings](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Kings "Los Angeles Kings") in the first game of the
series. Six days later on April 17, the franchise earned their first playoff
series win against the Kings, winning the fourth game by a 1–0 score, which
also became their first playoff series sweep. The Knights became the first
team in NHL history to sweep their first playoff series in their inaugural
season.[41] On May 6, 2018, the Golden Knights defeated the [San Jose
Sharks](/wiki/San_Jose_Sharks "San Jose Sharks") four-games-to-two, becoming
the third team in NHL history to win multiple playoff series in their
inaugural season, and advanced to the Western Conference Finals.[42] On May
20, Vegas defeated the [Winnipeg Jets](/wiki/Winnipeg_Jets "Winnipeg Jets") to
win the Western Conference Finals in five games, becoming the third NHL team
to advance to the [Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/Stanley_Cup_Finals "Stanley Cup
Finals") in its inaugural season, after the [Toronto
Arenas](/wiki/Toronto_Arenas "Toronto Arenas") in
[1918](/wiki/1918_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1918 Stanley Cup Finals") and the [St.
Louis Blues](/wiki/St._Louis_Blues "St. Louis Blues") in
[1968](/wiki/1968_Stanley_Cup_Finals "1968 Stanley Cup Finals").[43]

## Team
identity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Team identity")]

### Logos, colors, and
uniforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Logos, colors, and uniforms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/26/Vegas_Golden_Knights_secondary_logo.png/130px-
Vegas_Golden_Knights_secondary_logo.png)](/wiki/File:Vegas_Golden_Knights_secondary_logo.png)

[](/wiki/File:Vegas_Golden_Knights_secondary_logo.png "Enlarge")

The team's secondary logo

The team's primary logo is a [barbute](/wiki/Barbute "Barbute") helmet,
superimposed on a black and gold seal, with a V-shaped opening.[44][45] The
secondary logo is two crossing swords behind a red star, designed to resemble
a star found on the landmark [Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas
sign](/wiki/Welcome_to_Fabulous_Las_Vegas_sign "Welcome to Fabulous Las Vegas
sign").[45]

The team's primary color is [steel gray](/wiki/Steel_gray "Steel gray"), which
is said to represent "strength and durability".[45][1] The other team colors
are [gold](/wiki/Gold_\(color\) "Gold \(color\)"), [red](/wiki/Red "Red")
(found in the Las Vegas skyline and at [Red Rock
Canyon](/wiki/Red_Rock_Canyon_National_Conservation_Area "Red Rock Canyon
National Conservation Area")), and [black](/wiki/Black "Black") (for "power
and intensity").[1]

The first uniforms in Golden Knights team history were unveiled publicly on
June 20, 2017.[46]

### Name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Name")]

The team's name includes "Knights" as a homage to the [Black
Knights](/wiki/Army_Black_Knights "Army Black Knights") of the [United States
Military Academy](/wiki/United_States_Military_Academy "United States Military
Academy"), Foley's alma mater, and because [knights](/wiki/Knights "Knights")
were, according to Foley, "the epitome of the warrior class".[44][47] Foley
had hoped to name his team the Black Knights, but dropped that plan after
encountering resistance from federal officials. Foley was unable to call the
team the "Vegas Knights" due to the [London Knights](/wiki/London_Knights
"London Knights") owning the "Knights" name in Canada.[47][48][49]

"Golden" was included in the name because [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold") is, as
Foley stated, the "No. 1 precious metal", and because Nevada is the [largest
gold-producing state](/wiki/Gold_mining_in_Nevada "Gold mining in Nevada") in
the country.[47][45] "Las" was omitted from the team's name because, according
to Foley, residents tend to refer to the city simply as "Vegas", and because a
four-word name would have been too long.[50][45]

The [United States Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army")
initially expressed concern after the Golden Knights' name was announced,
because [their parachute team](/wiki/United_States_Army_Parachute_Team "United
States Army Parachute Team") uses the same nickname.[48] The Army later
disputed the trademark and colors of the team during its first season, to
which the team responded: "We are not aware of a single complaint from anyone
attending our games that they were expecting to see the parachute team and not
a professional hockey game."[51] An objection was also raised by the [College
of Saint Rose](/wiki/College_of_Saint_Rose "College of Saint Rose") because
its sports teams use the same name; the Vegas team's initial trademark
application was denied as a result, but was later approved on appeal.[52] The
team did clear the name with [Clarkson University](/wiki/Clarkson_University
"Clarkson University"), which also uses the name Golden Knights.[53]

###
Mascot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Mascot")]

The Golden Knights' [mascot](/wiki/Mascot "Mascot") is a [Gila
monster](/wiki/Gila_monster "Gila monster") named Chance. He was unveiled at
the team's second home game on October 13, 2017.[54][55] The team opted
against using a knight for a mascot because it found that knight mascots used
by other teams were not very child-friendly.[56]

## Team
information[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Team information")]

###
Broadcasting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Broadcasting")]

[AT&T SportsNet Rocky Mountain](/wiki/AT%26T_SportsNet_Rocky_Mountain "AT&T
SportsNet Rocky Mountain") (formerly Root Sports) is the regional television
rightsholder for all Golden Knights games not broadcast nationally by [NBCSN
or NBC](/wiki/NHL_on_NBC "NHL on NBC"). The team's designated market includes
Nevada, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Wyoming, and parts of Arizona and
California.[57][58][59] Golden Knights games on AT&T SportsNet are called by
former [Boston Bruins](/wiki/Boston_Bruins "Boston Bruins") radio announcer
[Dave Goucher](/wiki/Dave_Goucher "Dave Goucher") on [play-by-
play](/wiki/Sports_commentator "Sports commentator"), and [Shane
Hnidy](/wiki/Shane_Hnidy "Shane Hnidy"), who previously worked color for the
[Winnipeg Jets](/wiki/Winnipeg_Jets "Winnipeg Jets") on
[TSN](/wiki/The_Sports_Network "The Sports Network").[60]

The team has a three-year radio deal with [Lotus
Broadcasting](/wiki/Lotus_Broadcasting "Lotus Broadcasting").[61] Lotus airs
the team's games on its [Fox Sports Radio](/wiki/Fox_Sports_Radio "Fox Sports
Radio") affiliate, [KRLV 1340/98.9](/wiki/KRLV "KRLV").[61] KRLV fronts a
network of nine stations across Nevada, California, Arizona, and Utah.[62]

One game a week is also aired on the company's [ESPN Deportes
Radio](/wiki/ESPN_Deportes_Radio "ESPN Deportes Radio") affiliate, [KENO
1460](/wiki/KENO "KENO"), making the team one of only three in the NHL to
offer Spanish-language broadcasts.[63]

### Minor league
affiliate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Minor league affiliate")]

On May 16, 2017, the Golden Knights entered a multi-year affiliation agreement
with a [minor league](/wiki/Minor_league "Minor league") team, the [Chicago
Wolves](/wiki/Chicago_Wolves "Chicago Wolves") of the [American Hockey
League](/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American Hockey League"). Like most NHL-
AHL affiliation arrangements, the Golden Knights are able to transfer players
to and from the Wolves.[26] Although the Wolves are the Golden Knights
affiliate, the two teams do not share the same ownership. In addition to the
Wolves, the Golden Knights were affiliated with the [Quad City
Mallards](/wiki/Quad_City_Mallards "Quad City Mallards") of the
[ECHL](/wiki/ECHL "ECHL") for the [2017–18
season](/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_ECHL_season "2017–18 ECHL season"),[27] however,
the Mallards ceased operations after the one season.[64]

### Retired
numbers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vegas_Golden_Knights&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Retired numbers")]

The number 58 was retired by the team on March 31, 2018, in honor of the 58
victims killed in the [2017 Las Vegas shooting](/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_shooting
"2017 Las Vegas shooting").[68]

The team is also not able to issue the jersey number 99 to any of its players
as it was retired league-wide in honor of [Wayne Gretzky](/wiki/Wayne_Gretzky
"Wayne Gretzky") at the [2000 NHL All-Star
Game](/wiki/50th_National_Hockey_League_All-Star_Game "50th National Hockey
League All-Star Game").[69]

Vegas Golden Knights retired numbers No. | Player | Position | Career | No. retirement  
---|---|---|---|---  
**58** | [Victims of 2017 Las Vegas shooting](/wiki/2017_Las_Vegas_shooting "2017 Las Vegas shooting") | — | — | March 31, 2018
